author: @davidbommersbach5026
text: For anyone that is struggling with ValueError having to do with the nan in their data: df.dropna() will drop all rows that contain nan.

author: @mrinalmahajan6471
text: why are you not dropping rows with missing values, it gave me an error that data contains NAN values and i had to use dropna to remove such rows. Is there some way I can train my model on missing values so that I don't have to remove it myself.

author: @NPatel-vk5sk
text: one can also simply use "predictions = clf.predict(X)" then use below for loop to correct_count. This avoids the reshaping issues. For some strange reason, I get an accuracy of 67.6.    correct_count = 0  predictions = clf.predict(X)  print predictions  for x in range(1, test_size + 1):   if (predictions[x]==y[x]):    correct_count += 1  Also remember to convert int to float when calculating the accuracy.

author: @ianstream
text: Hi. Sentdex  Thank for your good lectures about ML and python  I'm studying by myself. But, I got a problem while doing this lecture.  python : 2.7.6 numpy : 1.9.2 source github : https://github.com/ianstream/Learning_scikit_learn/blob/master/14_scikit_learn.py   problem 1. I use your code. In Analysis function, test_size define "1000" and index nuxpy array from 0 to -test_size. But I got error like below     File "/home/ianstream/.local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/sklearn/svm/base.py", line 162, in fit     (X.shape[0], y.shape[0])) ValueError: X and y have incompatible shapes. X has 103685 samples, but y has 1991.   I google some info about these error. so, I change indexing condition from negative to positive. ex. X[:test_size],y[:test_size]  Then, I got other problem.   /home/ianstream/.local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/sklearn/utils/validation.py:386: DeprecationWarning: Passing 1d arrays as data is deprecated in 0.17 and willraise ValueError in 0.19. Reshape your data either using X.reshape(-1, 1) if your data has a single feature or X.reshape(1, -1) if it contains a single sample.   DeprecationWarning) ('Accuracy:', 0.0)   Could you give me some advise?

author: @citrus_maxima
text: since this is using numpy already, I find that this: correct_count = np.sum(clf.predict(X[-test_size:]) == y[-test_size:]) works well

author: @zwang5472
text: use train_test_split() to randomly split the data, and use confusion_matrix to insight the classification results.  60% accuracy for binary problem is slightly better than random guess.
